so if you have like a really experienced team you know you can get by with it um

formal specification technique which I think is it's really interesting and it's actually a lot of people in the embedded world use it you know we used
it on this Android project um we're also using it right now on like an embedded
project with you know like a 6 MHz microcontroller so it's kind of just like General technique it's not specific

game Perell um and back back in the 80s he was a like a new associate professor
in Israel for like math and computer science or mathematical logic or something and he got this pretty cool
gig where I think on on Thursdays he uh would go hang out with this uh like
consulting company you know this Computing consulting company and they had this project where they were actually building out all this avionic
software for this jet fighter right which is pretty cool um and you know harell does not know about jet fighters
he's like a math computer nerd so you know he's just showing up on Thursdays and hanging out with these guys to like
try and help them figure out stuff and what ended up happening is you know they they had all these specifications and
you know they'd read through them and he'd see what's going on and he basically just played this game of 20 questions where you know harell the new
guy this math guy would sit down and he'd be like okay so what happens when the pilot presses this button and then
what they would do is they' pull down all these finders and you know they' pull one of them and be like okay like bind your 3 subsection A4 when the pilot
presses this button like the plane is going to do this and then harell would go okay well like what if the plane is
like parked you know they oh if it's parked like and you press that button and they pull out in like another binder
and they're like so right here it says and the plane is parked and you press this button this other thing happens right and so he kind of plays this game
of 20 questions and they go back and forth to these binders but then after like the fourth or fifth question you know his client would be like uh I we
got to call the Air Force I don't know and so they'd call it the Air Force and they'd ask the same questions and then
you know by like the eighth or nth question Air Force would be like uh we don't know right like we looked at our
binders and we really have no idea like what's supposed to happen right um and so you know he's doing this you know
over the course of a couple months and what he ends up doing is he starts drawing all these little diagrams because he's Computer Science Guy um in
the margins of all these documents and you know how many people here are familiar with like finite State machines
like finite autom kind of stuff yeah so you know it's it's kind of like that you know he quickly notices that there are
these different states the plane can be in right like the plane can be parked on the ground like could be flying and then
there also you know kind of substates so in like traditional finite State atat you just have States and transitions
between them but he's drawing these diagrams he really wants to have kind of like sub States cuz it's like well when you're flying you could be doing like
you could be shooting at stuff you could be like being sneaky like there are these different substates that the plane could be in and so he's drawing these
diagrams and kind of you know figuring out like what happens when you're in this state and there substate and this event happens you go over here and you
know very quickly like they all start talking over these diagrams right they they put the binders aside and they're
all talking about this and he has this great story where one day um you know they have all this stuff up on a whiteboard right right and all talking
about it and then uh this pilot comes by right and the Pilot's like what's this
and they're like oh well you know they're the states and like you know these events happen and you go from here to here and you follow these arrows
right and the Pilot's looking at it and then after like two minutes the Pilot's like okay like down here I think you
know I think this needs to go over here right and he was right right which is amazing like that's an amazing Testament
to good notation because I don't I don't care what programming language you're using there's no way in hell your customer is going to walk by and like
look at your code and be like I don't think this is right you know like this is not going to happen with code and
that's one of the things that's really cool about these State charts is that you have this kind of map or this Visual
formalism and you know harell is a mathematical logic Professor so of course after this project he like writes
a paper about it and defines formal semantics which is great and this is actually a super readable paper right this is from 1987 um and I highly
recommend looking this up so he basically defined the behavior of his um
he has like a digital wrist watch you know with all the buttons and you can like set alarms and like you know make it beep and all this kind of stuff so he
like builds out this like state chart describing how the watch works and so it's a super readable I don't read
mathematical logic papers a lot but like this one's super readable and all these cool pictures and stuff like that um so
you know I I found that they're a really useful tool because they have a formal semantics and you can actually Implement them in code but at the same time you
can like show them to regular humans and be like hey does this look right you know like here's what's going on this is what we think you mean um and you can
have conversations with designers and customers and stuff like that so
um to give you an example in maybe a more familiar context I don't know how many people have worked on jet fighters
here um I'm was going to walk you through a simple state chart just to give you a flavor of what it looks like
and the example I'm going to use is just like a login flow right so you have an app you need to log in before you can
like get that do some cool stuff in the app so you know you start you just draw
out and think about the states that you have um right so you might have a login state so we're just indicating that like

screen which is like you can submit some credentials to try and log in right and
for anyone who's implemented this you know you don't you don't actually go straight into the app when this happens

application is waiting like you've grayed out some boxes and you have like the spinning wheel or whatever and your person's waiting so you're in this kind
of like logging in state um which is a little different and then at that point you know maybe the server gets back to

right your credentials might be invalid you go back to the login screen you know or maybe after 5 Seconds you know your
your local app gives up on the server and like sends someone to like a timeout screen and it says like sorry like the server's down try again later um you
know so this is a really simple example but already like having a little picture like this I find much clearer than like
just spec like a written spec um and again the thing that's cool about State
charts is that it's not like a finite State machine where all the states are at the same level you can have this notion of hierarchy so to bring it back
to the example of technicians using this like inspection application um you could
say like actually you know that at the very high level we want to design this app and say like you're either online or
offline right maybe we only want the login flow to work when you have an online connection right so you could
like shrink that down and say like okay you're either offline or online you're going to start in some offline State and
then at some point you might get a connect message at another point you might get a disconnect message and like you know you would kind of read this
diagram in hopefully a way that seems uh somewhat natural right so like if you're in the offline oh you can't see my
little pointer uh if you're in a little offline State you can connect you go inside the online State and since that
has substates you kind of recurse into it and so the default state in the online State you start the login screen
right and at any point in any of those States if you get a disconnect message you know you're getting sent back to the
offline state so you know this is kind of a nice thing because it it lets you kind of hierarchically decompose the
behavior of your application um and kind of think like it helps I mean for me
having to think abstractly about the States before you dive into the code is really nice because like you can draw these little diagrams and talk with your

programming stuff it's like we have function we want to handle two different cases like we're going to use a argument

like this huge and uh we're making a mobile app is this B right so he'll
often times when he's doing the design stuff he will call the function a lot and just make a bunch of versions of

right so you could call this login template and see like hey what does it look like when like someone has a long name and a short name and their

you know they can just reach in and say like okay this is what I'm working on I'm going to just grab this function I'm going to call it I'm see what it looks

for the developers is I can't really it's hard to underscore this enough like but like functions are really nice you
know they compose in these nice ways so um this is an example this code is like
the little widget that's getting clicked on so this is basically polymorphic depending on the kind of observation
you're making so depending on the equipment and stuff it's like you might need to say this is a true false statement or like this is a drop- down

stuff like that we can encapsulate all that stuff into a function and then we can just call it where we need it right
there's none of this weird like we have these weird nested templates and like we don't know where things come from and
like we don't know how to Nest them together it's like you can do all this stuff with functions and like data it's
really nice um so you know functions are really nice it's it's just like you
don't have to use closure or Ruby you can do all the in Java right I write really weird like functional Java which
is just like you have a lot of static methods um and you return values and you just put them together and it's fine
um but what's kind of interesting is you know you can take this idea much further
is that like okay well we made each screen as a function you know you kind of Nest these things together and stuff what you can do is you can make your
entire UI as a single function right like you can you can turn this up to 11
and like really run with it um and what this there's actually a name for this which is called like an immediate mode
UI which is basically you have this render function and uh it renders your entire application right um as a
function so calling all these things and at some point you know you call this render with something gives you this big pile of HTML and that's what's on the
screen and it sort of raises a question like what's this guy right it's like that's the state of your application
it's the entire state of your application it's right there um and a bunch of nice things actually fall out
having an explicit state for your application right so if anything changes in your application like if you open up
a menu or something this needs to change a little right um because the entire
application is getting rendered from this state and this function uh and you
can you know model this in a lot of different ways like in some ways you can just have like a map you know you can
have a nested map of all these different details and stuff like that um on this particular project we actually used a a
mutable graph database in uh on the client but that's that's a beer talk so
uh you know we can talk about that more later but there's actually there's just a bunch of benefits from having the
application State be explicit you can have a single reference to it and the first and foremost is that it's viewable
right you could like print it to the console and you could be like why does my application look like this and you print it out and you look and you're
like okay like here's the data for the application here's a function that is going on you can figure out what's going on um you know that's a developer thing
uh another case of like where this is actually really cool outside of just development life is that if you have explicit application State you can
serialize it which means that when someone's in a big truck in the middle of desert and your app breaks like you
don't have to play this weird phone tag game with them where you're like okay you're on the home screen and then you click on something and then you like you
take out your phone and you click on it and you're like and then what do you do and you click on that and like you kind of you know it's like you can actually
just say like this thing is broken we're going to serialize the entire application State and submit it with the bug report and then you can just get
that play around with it figure out what's going on um this this is a huge it's a huge win right cuz it sucks
